in "your free to do whatever you want to" at the end, you show a page of he music written out and I was wondering why you start the song in G#- but then you go to Ab. Why did you spell it like that? was it a ease of reading kind of thing?

just trying to keep the key signature under 6 flats/sharps. Ab minor has Cb and Fb. G# major has B sharp, E sharp, and F double sharp. I realize the intro doesn't even really use the minor, but i think when i wrote the intro i was probably planning to keep it all minor. but then the life happens and it went major

any tips on how to start turning ideas of music into actual finished songs?

sure. start asking questions about it. the first thing to ask is whether the piece you have should be at the beginning. if you think it is, then try to figure out what comes next. i have tips for that too, but only if the answer to 'is it the beginning' is yes. If you think it's not the beginning, then the next step is to figure out what comes before. this is harder and much more mysterious to figure out. i have tips for that too, but only if the answer to 'is it the beginning' is no

what is the meaning of life, didn't you say you found it, do you still hesitate to say it?

the thing about it is, when we say "it" it sounds like something you can count. it sounds like 1, really. if someone says "found it", how many things do we think they are talking about? 1, probably. well the thing about the *meaning of life* is, ............. most of the time, the quantity it seems to be dealing with is more 'infinite' in style. which, strangely, can almost appear identical to the number '0', any time you try to quantify it or do any definitive reporting on it.. so it's not so much hesitation, it's more just like that stupid feeling when you're a math teacher and one day you have to say "ok folks, here's something called the 'reflexive property' which says a=a. it literally means things equal themselves. wasn't that important, aren't you glad i said that, don't you feel like that was an important use of time to say that"

yes. i will tell you my story, in context, so you can make your decision. i used to think it was better to put the desk against the wall, facing toward the wall, because it gives you more space in the room. but then, at some point, right around when i was facing one of the more severe brickwalls in my development as a writer, just 1 day after the really really dark day when i sort of made a declaration that this is impossible and i can't do this, i had a breakthrough and rearranged the desk, to be facing away from the wall. and this changed everything. i didn't expect this but it ended up being the magic key to everything. things seem to be better if the desk faces the generally toward the door (but is on the opposite side of the room). basically if you can imagine it as an office where people might come in to meet with you occasionally. for some reason that makes all the difference

what do you think i should do?

bridge only is probably just about the hardest to work with. but, just play process of elimination. play 'what do we know.'
gradually quiz yourself on things about the 'other part' (ANY other part) of the song. for example, does it live mostly on the 1 chord? is it a 4 first? maybe start asking yourself little questions about what should categorically be immediately before it. you will get an average of maybe 23% of an answer to each of these little questions. just keep asking the questions and you will gradually hone in on useful information. how about this: what should come after it. that will still get you close to figuring out everything else. Another general principle to remember is making patterns and breaking them. Whatever patterns are in the part you have, ask yourself what it would mean to break those patterns in the other part. or, this might be a slightly harder question, but what is a pattern such that your section (that you already have) would be good at breaking. Here's another even more scientific approach. just try putting things before it. then analyze exactly why you hated it so much, if at all. whether you liked any of them or hated any of them, with each one you will get just a bit more glimmer of information about what kinds of things are working and what is not

it's good to make sure you have a direct line of communication going with the exact original circumstances in which the project was selected. there is a certain phenomenon i've noticed, in these situations, and the phenomenon is called 'the first version is the best one you're gonna get'.
i'll tell you the 2 most distinctive times i remember that being proven for me. the first day writing 'just did a bad thing', i made it through the 1st verse (double verse), through 'cancelled', and sing the connecting riff and suddenly land into this full 16 bar chorus, which fully came to me very quickly, which i was thrilled about, but it absolutely didn't seem to fit with the rest of the song (the 'bad thing' song). it was the entire 'hey, what's the name of this game' section, exactly how you hear it on the recording. that was what originally came, springing straight from that little connecting riff (after 'cancelled'). i was quite disappointed, i loved it but it just didn't seem to fit with that song. so i marked it down as 'hey what's the name of this game', as a different song, to be dealt with another time. Then i tried something totally different there. something about science or something, not anything sounding like the chorus as you know it. tried several different ideas for what could go after 'cancelled'. and by the end of the day, simply nothing was sticking. every attempt seemed to have less validity than the previous. i noticed this decrease in validity as the iterations wore on. so i knew there really was no choice but to return to the 'hey what's the name of this game' and trust that it can go in 'bad thing.' and i'm glad i did. and this is not the first time this has happened, it happens all the time. the most similar time i can think of is in 'sexy pants', almost exactly the same story, with the entire 16 bar thing at 'every day is such a lovely day' etc. that whole thing came very quickly, but i was disappointed to realize it really doesn't belong in that song, so i put it aside and tried to come up with the right thing but each attempt was increasingly more doubtable so i had really no choice but to go back to the first one. i've generally accepted this as a common princicple, that if you find yourself deleting and redoing something several times, you kind of have no choice but to just go with whichever version you thought of first. and just accept it as part of the thrill ride of songwriting, which sometimes is to be forced to work with crap. sometimes the best songwriting is when you think your partner or coworker has just handed you a piece of crap, and now you gotta make it work some how

Hi Bill! I love your music and also I've read a few of these questions and your music advice seems really solid. My question is, do you have any advice for understanding how time signatures work?
I'm new to music theory and having a hard time getting my head around this particular concept.

first get a metronome. that's just like a 'clicker'. just download one and you'll see what i mean. it just makes a constant click. and you can set the speed (tempo). ok now turn it off, and listen to some songs. see if you can find the 'beat', in those songs. the 'beat' is like the steady click, and most songs have it, all the way through. it is what people 'tap their foot' to, or, i think a couple days ago someone accused me of 'nodding my head' up and down while playing music. that would be the same thing. listen to every song you know and see if you can find this pulse. for most songs, it goes all the way through. But, .... there's more.... What if i told you that these beats could be organized in groups of 2. So imagine if you're hearing the steady click, but you're seeing a flash of light on the 1st, 3rd, 5th, 7th, (althernating) clicks. i hope this is making sense so far. or maybe just every alternating click is louder. so like, CLICK click CLICK click CLICK click. it might not actually be louder in the music, but it feels like a miniature starting place, every 2 clicks. it's hard to explain, i just realized. i've been familiar with this probabaly since before i could speak language, so i hope it's something you can get because i actually just realized i have no way of explaining it. Also, just to make sure we're on the same page, try to make sure the tempo is usually somewhere between 70 and 140 -- just listen to those tempos on your metronome to get an idea of roughly the speeds i'm talking about, so when you listen to songs, you can find the beat in that range (not like doubled or quadrupled or something). So as you listen to songs, try to ask yourself, can you feel the clicks, and can you also feel how one out of every 2 clicks seems to feel like the dominant one. Hopefully this is making sense. it's much easier to actually demonstrate than to explain in only words. So i think you'll find that almost every song you can find, has these beats, in groups of 2 like this. Well, if you take it a step further, you will find that these groups of 2 also seem to come in groups of 2. so that makes groups of 4 clicks. see if you can listen to some songs and see if you can find the beat, and see if you can hear which one is the first of the group of 4. see if you can hear it in groups of 4. at least 90% of all songs in the world will use this 4 pattern. This means that the timesignature of the song is 4. actually on paper this is written with two 4s on top of each other, but that's not really that important. the time signature is called "4 4", pronounced "four four". but in actual reality you can just say the song is "in 4". and literally every musician on the planet will know exactly what you mean. Most songs are in 4, kind of like most cars have 4 wheels, and most people walk in a repeating 2 pattern (which, when superimposed on itself at halfspeed, creates 4, which is exactly the way it occurs in music). It's just a natural property of nature that music tends to operate this way also. a "bar" is just 4 beats. so if a song has a time signature of 4 (or "four four", again, it's sort of a long boring historic story as to why it's called that), it means there are 4 beats in a bar. Most music is like this, for most of the time. But, a LOT of songs, ESPECIALLY when transitioning between sections, like going from the verse to the chorus, or from the chorus to the verse, may break this pattern momentarily, in between sections. This is normal. It's like that left-right walking pattern -- it gets interrupted when you get onto your bike, but then while you are on the bike the pattern is back to normal. and then it gets weird again for 1 or 2 steps as you get off the bike. This technically means the time signature changed (to maybe 1, or 5, or whatever you need) just for that one moment when you got off the bike. This again is natural in nature, for patterns to occasionally need to break in order to pass from one scenario to the next. More rarely, you might occasionally find songs that actually seem to consistently have 3 beats per bar. This means the time signature is 3, or, traditionally on paper this is written as 3 4 (the 3 is written directly above the 4, and it's pronounced "three four"). Again, it's kind of a long boring historic story as to why the 4 is written under there, but it's the top number that really tells you how many beats per bar. But if you imagine the tempo differently, you might not need to write it in 3. for example, if it's 3 very quick beats, you might even imagine them all as just 1 beat. and guess what ....... those big 1 beats are definitely going to usually come in groups of 4. so either the time signature is 4 (and the tempo is slow) and the beats happen to be broken in groups of 3 (those would be called 'triplets') OR, you can say it's in a time signature of 3, and the beats go by 3 times quicker ('tempo' would be therefore be 3 times faster on paper), and you are hearing groups of 4 ENTIRE BARS. ..... Now, here's the thing, ... when you're learning about time signatures, it's going to be tempting to ask 'well what would happen if there was a weirder grouping like 5, 7, or 11.' Well, this is ok, and it's a fun question to ask, but there is diminishing effectiveness as the numbers get weirder, although it's tempting to think that's a good idea while you are learning, because your brain is focused on it. However, it still remains true that these weird numbers are very commonly used MOMENTARILY, like when going from one section to the next. Or, just, if you have a special lyric in there that needs more or less time. Music lives and dies by the element of surprise, so this will be necessary. But when it comes to keeping a steady time signature for a long period of time, you will find that 4 will be it, at least 90% of the time. about 8% of the time it will be 3, but again it's always debatable whether it's actually just a slow 4 with triplets in each beat. Less than 1%, you may actually find a consistent 5. and in at least half of those cases of 5, the number 5 will actually be in the title of the song, because as i said, it's usually a very deliberate mental exercise. This is increasingly true as you start to use larger prime numbers (7, 11, 13, etc), and if you see those used steadily over the course of long periods of time (such as an entire song) it becomes increasingly likely that the composer wants you to know they are thinking about the time signature. as tempting and fun as it is, to dwell on these scenarios for the sake of learning, it also seems necessary to mention the significance and importance of '4' because we often overlook this, if we become 'interested' in time signatures, which you may have, based on your question. Now, you may think, 'well, are you saying that we should strive to be boring and normal', and the answer is no. but in the greater scheme of things, if you're gonna be free then probably wouldn't even want to restrict yourself to a time signature at all. so, weirdly, doing a song in 7 and staying in 7 is actually more restrictive than just keeping it in 4...... Four is usually what happens when you are not trying to actively focus on the time signature, AND, what i would like to mention again is that very often you get deviations from this, but NOT in a way that stays that way constantly -- it will be usually just when you need to get from one place to the next. so it's almost not even fair to count that as a 'different time signature', and in many of those cases it's literally not a different time signature because the tempo pauses itself completely for an undefined amount of time. i would estimate that this may happen in at least 30% of all songs, very broadly speaking. in conclusion, the time signature is usually 4, but i don't necessarily expect you to believe me at this point

how was the writing process for "i'm best friends with my own front door"?

very fast. i had just snapped and said 'i'm going to do these music videos in 2 weeks even though i know it always takes 10 weeks no matter how hard i try to make it 2 weeks or even 4 weeks, but now i'm desperate, it's gonna be 2 weeks or die trying', and so there was no time to waste. and on the selection, i seemed to hate everything (as usual), so because the time was so limited, part of my brain just said 'what song do you wish you could do' (like one that doesn't exist yet), and the first 2 lines wrote themself. So that was the starting point, then i began writing it, and i think after the whole day i still really had barely even wrapped up the first 2 stanzas. not good, because there's only 14 days to do the whole process, ..... write, record everything, all everything, video, ..... entire everything. So i took a panic walk and slapped myself into shape and realized if i can't finish this in the next 4 hours then i'm off the bus pretty much. So basically the first thing that was written after the switch into panic mode was the 'i saw the sign' bit. i think it's evident that this wouldn't have made it into the song if i had had time to think. but in fact, it's this line that is the gateway to the entire mindset of the rest of the song. it sends it off a sort of cliff, and a series of strange things unfold, and due to momentum, when we finally land at the 'outchorus' ('do everything'.... etc), the real-world emotion of the actual scenario seems to realize itself more fully and genuinely, and the song is definitely about itself, as you can see the victory set in towards the end, and yet also admitting how it had seemed like the end of the world just moments ago which i narrowly escaped

I am trying to write songs but most ideas are extremely similar to your old jingles. maybe because ive spent an embarassingly long amount of time looking at them, or maybe because i enjoy them the most (my conspiracy theory is, it's a combination of both). how do i grow out of copying someone and thinking more originally?

there are 2 things you can do. listen to at least 100 other artists. then, besides that, try to write something that ABSOLUTELY none of those artists have ever done. to make this easier for yourself, temporarily waive the requirement that they are supposed to be 'good'. try to do something incorrect and horrendous with the music. What this does is it taunts the music gods, provokes them, and they will try to get their revenge by making the music good anyway. And you will see that the path it takes FROM that horrendous place, back to a more familiar place, will be very interesting, and still quite different from most things you've heard, while still being good

I've got many things to do but I dont know which one to do first so I just end up doing nothing. Can you help me figure out a method of solving this? Thanks in advance

here's what i would recommend, based on similar long term problems i've had, and the best solution that has emerged. it's a hybrid randomization scheme. First, put all the items in a list. 2 different approaches come to mind- 1: using complete randomization to pick (computer generated random selection), but this might end up picking one that you actually don't really want to do. 2: 'just picking the one you want' clearly doesn't work, otherwise you wouldn't be in this situation. So i've found a hybrid system: the way it works is, first you go through the list and choose ones that you think are reasonable choices -- it's ok to pick as many as you want. Add these to a finalists list. then, immediately as soon as you finish making that list, do a random selection based on that new list. And that's your selection. If you don't end up choosing any for the finalists list, then go ahead and just do the random selection on the original list. i hope this helps. i think it is a solid system and it works for me, even in the face of extreme decision anxiety

Is it possible to charm a police officer with your music?

yes, but i think i missed the perfect opportunity. this is kind of a long story but hopefully you can follow... one time i was driving through a mandatory sobriety check point. they looked at my license and asked me to say the alphabet. But i've heard so many stories about police asking you to say the alphabet BACKWARDS, that in my mind i thought that's what they said. And it just so happens that as a child i familiarized myself with a fully functional version of the common ABC song, with backwards lyrics, so the alphabet is in reverse. So i have the backwards alphabet very readily commited to memory. So i started blasting through the backwards alphabet (not in song, just spoken) and i already got to about Q when he said 'whoa whoa whoa, no, forwards.' and he probably thought i was crazy. Everything worked out fine, but unfortunately i missed the opportunity to simply press play on the CD in the CD player, which happened to be a test mix of my 'Alphabet Shuffle' song, which i had been listening to moments before. i understand this story would have been better if i had actually done it, but for some reason it didn't seem like a good idea at the time

Hey bill if you wanna make your life easier when it comes to figuring out if something is a multiple of 7, there's a convenient way to use your subtract/add a multiple of 7 trick that makes it much easier.Say your number is 30583 for example.Now we know that 21 is a multiple of 7 right?That means anything times 21 is also a multiple of 7.So what we can do is just subtract the number by 21 times the last digit of the number, in this case 3.So 21*3=63 which means we can do 30583-63->30520 then divide by 10 to get 3052.Then repeat.3052-42->3010->301 301-21->280->28 which is divisible by 7 which means 30583 is divisible by 7.Now whenever we are subtracting by 21 times the last digit and then dividing by 10, what we are essentially doing is taking the last digit, doubling it, then subtracting the rest of the number by t he doubl ed last digit.So like instead of doing 30583-63->30520->3058 what you can instead do is a short cut for 30583 and take the last digit 3, double it to get 6, and then subtract the rest of the number by that doubled digit, 3058-6->3052, and then just keep subtracting the rest of the number by the last digit doubled until you get to a number you know is divisible by 7.

how did you get the original inspiration for "got to know what's going on"? (love that song by the way)

i think we all just want to understand how the world really works, and what is really going on, and what everything is and means. i came up with the first line of the chorus, and many others, many years before i would have had the courage to take care of the entire songwriting, especially because dealing with a song where you only know the chorus, and then figuring out what comes before, is a very weird puzzle that i didn't learn how to do until years later. in fact i didn't even really have the courage to finish the chorus either, until years later. it was quite common for me to come up with quite normal sounding hooks and not know what to do with them, and back then (around 2010) my only strategy was to start at the beginning and go bonkers, from beginning to end. but there were many chorus-sounding figures that were generated at that time, such as 'i'm sad', 'i wanna go home', etc, which i didn't really know how to deal with. As of june 2017, recording songs regularly, my selection process was brute force random-number selection -- no pre-selection, no semi-finals, just get a randomly generated number out of 400 (or however many items there were in the list at the time) and you absolutely have to pick that one, no matter what it is. So that one came up and was still just a 1 line figure. so that's when the rest of it was written
